questions.question_text: Which configuration saves the running configuration to the startup configuration and logs a “saving configuration automatically” message when a syslog message that contains “SYS-5-CONFIG_I” is received?

comments.content: You need to have an enable first as bigyan said, I've done this before and you should start with action 1.0 cli command "enable".
I think C is right. Switch has to go to user exce mode for the 'wr mem' to work. 'end' will take to user exec mode directly from other modes.

discussion.content:
All options are wrong
Option C could be correct if action 1.0 has enable instead of end
action 1.0 cli command "enable"

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer
"SYS-5-CONFIG_I" This pattern appears when you do a config change in the conf t mode.
so the purpose of this script is to save the running config every time someone changes any configuration.

and also this pattern will only appear when the configuration has been made through an interactive session "_I".

so after we concluded that this pattern appeared in conf t we can all agree that the script needs to use the command "end" before applying the save running command

Selected Answer: D
For me... option C and D are correct doing the same thing (tested EVE-NG)... but we have to choose one.. For me I will go with D because if we have 2 users configuring and one of them exits the conf mode, option C will close the conf mode for the 2nd user.

Selected Answer: D
See for yourself:

R1#conf t
Enter configuration commands, one per line. End with CNTL/Z.
R1(config)#event manager applet save_config
R1(config-applet)#event syslog pattern "%SYS-5-CONFIG_I" period 1
R1(config-applet)#action 1.0 cli command "write mem"
R1(config-applet)#action 2.0 syslog msg "saving configuration automatically"
R1(config-applet)#exit
R1(config)#end
R1#
*Feb 12 21:20:49.811: %SYS-5-CONFIG_I: Configured from console by console
R1#
*Feb 12 21:20:49.948: %HA_EM-6-LOG: save_config: saving configuration automatically
R1#
R1#sh event manager history events 
No. Job Id Proc Status Time of Event Event Type Name
1 1 Actv success Wed Feb12 21:20:49 2025 syslog applet: save_config

Selected Answer: D
A: Wrong --- There is no event track command
B: Wrong --- There is no string match command
C: Wrong --- No inverted commas after the command in action 2.0
D: Correct --- Tested in the lab environment.
Note: "enable" command not required because the prompt is already in privilege mode when "SYS-5-CONFIG_I" message appears.
This would be soo much better question if one answer would have "do write mem" to solve this end/enable discussion.

event manager applet save_config
event syslog pattern "SYS-5-CONFIG_I" 
#this pattern appears when you do a config change in the conf t mode.
action 1.0 cli command "enable" 
#Enter privileged mode
action 2.0 cli command "wr me"
#Save the current conf
action 3.0 syslog msg "saving configuration automatically"
#send a syslog message

all option are wrong it should be as below according to my understanding 
event manager applet SaveConfig
 event syslog pattern "SYS-5-CONFIG_I"
 action 1.0 cli command "enable"
 action 2.0 cli command "copy running-config startup-config"
 action 3.0 syslog msg "saving configuration automatically"

Selected Answer: C
Answer should be C, the others don't make complete sense

Selected Answer: A
A is the Answear. Computer says.
a data taht is usefull "SYS-5-CONFIG_I" is activated when someone enter the command "conf term", so for wri mem you neeed to "back" to enable

comments.content: soory, my bad... if you see "SYS-5-CONFIG_I" you have returned form condf term to enable level (exit ussually) so the "end" is not needed (if you use "end" in enable level, the equipment will try toi find the domain). So, the answer would be D

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The syslog pattern would be triggered after someone exited from configuration mode (using end or exit). So no need for action 'end' and no need to 'enable' as it would already be enabled.

Agree with all of you, C is then the best of the worst

event manager applet save_config
 event syslog pattern "SYS-5-CONFIG_I" period 1
 action 1.0 cli command "enable"
 action 2.0 cli command "wr mem"
 action 3.0 syslog msg "saving config"
bigyan are absolutely right, i've tested on eve and only worked after put command "enable" first

choices.C:

choices.D:

R1(config-if)# ip nat outside

R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/1

R1(config-if)# ip nat inside -
choices.B:
R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/0

R1(config-if)# ip pat outside -

R1(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/1

R1(config-if)# ip pat inside -

comments.content:
1. You misread the IP, it is 192.168.10.17, but it doesn't really matter, it could be anything.
2. The first IP in the static NAT command is always the inside local IP, which is routed on the inside interface.

ip nat inside source static 192.168.10.17 192.168.27.42

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Why not correct answer is D?
192.160.10.17 is a public address, so G0/1 interface should be outside and G0/0 inside.

pat -> multiple
nat -> 1-1

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
agree with A

Selected Answer: A
It is as the haze roamer is stating, answer A

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.
"ip pat" isn't a command, so that strikes B and C.
D has the inside/outside interfaces swapped per the existing config.

questions.question_text: Which type of roaming event occurs when a client roams across multiple mobility groups?

discussion.content:
Should be L3: C
When a client crosses a mobility group boundary while a roam, the client is fully authenticated, but the IP address is maintained, and EtherIP tunneling is initiated for Layer 3 roaming.

comments.content: Inter Controller-L3 Roaming : If the clients roam between APs registered to different controllers and the client WLAN on the two controllers is on different subnet, then it is called inter-controller L3 roam.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
L3, intercontroller roam between mobility groups

Selected Answer: C
L2 : Same VLAN, Same mobility group
L3 : Different VLAN or mobility group

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
see Q #958
There's no mention in the question of different subnets (VLANs), so this is Inter Controller L2 roaming. D

Selected Answer: C
L3 as per explanation below

Layer 2 & Layer 3 Intercontroller Roam

When a mobile client roams from one AP to another, and if those APs are on different WLCs, then the client makes an intercontroller roam.

When a client starts an intercontroller roam, the two WLCs compare the VLAN IDs allocated to their WLAN interfaces.
– If the VLAN IDs are the same, the client performs a Layer 2 intercontroller roam.
– If the VLAN IDs are different, the WLCs will arrange a Layer 3 or local-to-foreign roam.

comments.content: The answer is C i.e. Layer3. Reason: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/4400-series-wireless-lan-controllers/107188-mobility-groups-faq.html#:~:text=Through%20seamless%20roaming%2C%20the%20client,address%20across%20all%20mobility%20groups.

This is what the OCG says in chapter 19, Intercontroler Roaming

If they don't mention any about VLANs... should be a L2 roaming

questions.question_text: A Cisco administrstor deploys a new wireless network but CAPWAP APs cannot communicate with the wireless controller. IP connectivity in the network functions properly. Which action resolves the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
-> UDP port 5246 is used for CAPWAP control traffic.
-> UDP port 5247 is used for CAPWAP data traffic.
If these ports are blocked, the APs will not be able to establish a CAPWAP tunnel with the controller, which is necessary for communication between the APs and the WLC.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
CAPWAP uses UDP ports 5246 (control channel) and 5247 (data channel).

Selected Answer: B
UDP ports 5246 and 5247 are the designated ports for CAPWAP control and data traffic, respectively. If these ports are blocked by a firewall, the APs cannot establish a connection with the WLC.

Selected Answer: B
Those are the correct port numbers

choices.D: Ensure that the controller is connected to a AAA server.
choices.A: Open CAPWAP UDP port 12222 in the network firewall.
choices.C: Enable the UDP Lite feature on the WLC.
choices.B: Open CAPWAP UDP ports 5246 and 5247 in the network firewall.
